A Study of the Edge-Switching Markov-Chain Method for the Generation of Random Graphs

Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

Abstract

We study the problem of generating connected random graphs with no self-loops or multiple edges and that, in addition, have a given degree sequence. The generation method we focus on is the edge-switching Markov-chain method, whose functioning depends on a parameter wğ‘¤witalic_w related to the methodâ€™s core operation of an edge switch. We analyze two existing heuristics for adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w during the generation of a graph and show that they result in a Markov chain whose stationary distribution is uniform, thus ensuring that generation occurs uniformly at random. We also introduce a novel wğ‘¤witalic_w-adjusting heuristic which, even though it does not always lead to a Markov chain, is still guaranteed to converge to the uniform distribution under relatively mild conditions. We report on extensive computer experiments comparing the three heuristicsâ€™ performance at generating random graphs whose node degrees are distributed as power laws.


Keywords: Random-graph generation, Edge switch, Markov chain.

We consider in this paper the problem of generating graphs of ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniformly at random when Dğ·Ditalic_D is realizable.

In the absence of the connectivity constraint, the problem of generating random graphs for a given degree sequence is closely related to some other problems, like generating a (0,1)01(0,1)( 0 , 1 ) matrix with given marginals [25], approximating the permanent of a matrix [19], and sampling a perfect matching or an fğ‘“fitalic_f-factor of a graph [14, 5]. However, it remains generally unknown how to generate graphs uniformly at random for a given degree sequence within reasonable time bounds [26], even though exceptions exist for some special cases, like regular [21] and bipartite graphs [14, 19].

The problem of generating random graphs has recently acquired considerable prominence from a practical perspective. Since many real-world networks, like the Internet, the WWW, social networks, and scientific-collaboration networks, typically have a very large number of nodes and have evolved over time in such an unorganized way that only limited information is known about their topologies [3, 24], many studies of their properties have been conducted within a random-graph framework [2, 15]. In addition, these networks are now known to differ sharply from the classical random-graph model introduced by ErdÅ‘s and RÃ©nyi [12, 8], in which the node-degree distribution is the Poisson distribution. Some empirical studies suggest that many of them have node-degree distributions that seem to conform to a power law [13, 6, 3, 24], that is, the probability that a randomly chosen node has degree ağ‘aitalic_a is proportional to aâˆ’Ï„superscriptğ‘ğœa^{-\tau}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some Ï„>1ğœ1\tau>1italic_Ï„ > 1.

Clearly, any method for sampling a graph uniformly at random from ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a given Dğ·Ditalic_D can be easily extended to generate random graphs having a power-law node-degree distribution. We first obtain Dğ·Ditalic_D by sampling each djsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—d_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the power-law distribution. If Dğ·Ditalic_D turns out not to be realizable, then we discard it entirely and obtain a new one, repeating this process while needed. We then select the desired graph uniformly at random from ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Other, more complex methods for generating random graphs having node degrees distributed as a power law have been proposed. In these methods, generation is achieved by successively adding nodes and edges to the graph in such a way that tries to follow some principles, like preferential attachment, that are believed to have guided the evolution of some real-world networks [22, 9]. However, simply generating a graph having a given degree sequence sampled from the power-law distribution has been observed to perform satisfactorily with regard to certain measures [27]. Moreover, this approach can be used to obtain random graphs having any node-degree distribution, which is an important flexibility since correctly determining the node-degree distribution of real-world networks has remained essentially an open problem [1].

Given a realizable Dğ·Ditalic_D, we consider the generation method that we call the edge-switching Markov-chain (ESMC) method for choosing graphs from ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniformly at random, also variously known by other denominations [16]. This method, which can be modeled as a Markov chain and whose details are more thoroughly described in SectionÂ 2, employs an operation that we call an edge switch to transform a graph of ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into another graph, maybe not in ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by virtue of not being connected, that has the same degree sequence Dğ·Ditalic_D. Let GğºGitalic_G be the graph being generated. To avoid generating unconnected graphs, we periodically perform a connectivity test on GğºGitalic_G. If GğºGitalic_G is unconnected, we undo all the edge switches performed since the previous connectivity test. Basically, the method consists of first obtaining a graph GğºGitalic_G from ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT deterministically and then applying a series of edge switches and connectivity tests to GğºGitalic_G until a certain halting condition is satisfied. We also discuss in SectionÂ 2 a methodology for obtaining the halting condition, which ultimately also embodies a criterion for estimating how close GğºGitalic_G is to a uniformly random sample from ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The ESMC method is intrinsically based on an integer parameter wâ‰¥1ğ‘¤1w\geq 1italic_w â‰¥ 1 giving the number of edge switches to be attempted between successive connectivity tests. Naturally, setting wğ‘¤witalic_w appropriately is crucial to the performance of the method. When wğ‘¤witalic_w is too small, a large number of connectivity tests is performed, which dramatically increases the running time of the method, as the time complexity of a connectivity test is high in comparison to the time complexity of an edge switch. On the other hand, when wğ‘¤witalic_w is excessively large the probability that the connectivity test is performed on an unconnected graph tends to be high, possibly causing many edge switches to be undone. Obtaining an ideal value for wğ‘¤witalic_w beforehand seems to be an elusive goal, so heuristics have been proposed for adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w along the algorithmâ€™s execution [16, 29]. We discuss the existing heuristics, and also introduce a new one, in SectionÂ 3.

We present in SectionÂ 4 the results of extensive computer experiments for degree sequences sampled from power-law distributions. We evaluate the three heuristics described in SectionÂ 3 along with two different halting conditions. In general, our computational results indicate that, on average, our heuristic outperforms the two existing heuristics in terms of the total running time by a margin of 12%percent1212\%12 % to 86%percent8686\%86 %. We conclude in SectionÂ 5.

2 The ESMC method

We henceforth denote by GğºGitalic_G the graph being generated, that is, the graph on which the edge switches and the connectivity tests are performed. An edge switch is performed on a pair of nonadjacent edges (i.e., edges that share no nodes) and consists of removing them from GğºGitalic_G and adding back one of two other pairs of edges. The pair of edges to be added to GğºGitalic_G is chosen at random from these two and the edge switch is only carried through if neither edge of the chosen pair already exists in GğºGitalic_G. In order to obtain the initial graph, we employ the Havel-Hakimi algorithm [18, 17, 7], which successively adds edges to an initial graph GğºGitalic_G having nğ‘›nitalic_n isolated nodes. At this moment, GğºGitalic_G has degree sequence Dğ·Ditalic_D but may be unconnected. Since Dğ·Ditalic_D is realizable, GğºGitalic_G must contain a cycle if it is not connected. If we take an edge of this cycle and an edge of another connected component, and perform an edge switch on them, then necessarily two of the connected components of GğºGitalic_G are merged together into a single one. This process can be repeated until GğºGitalic_G becomes connected.

Let us then describe what constitutes a transition in â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M. Let wâ‰¥1ğ‘¤1w\geq 1italic_w â‰¥ 1 be an integer parameter. A transition in â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M is a sequence of wğ‘¤witalic_w steps that we call edge-switching attempts. In each edge-switching attempt, we randomly select two distinct edges of GğºGitalic_G. If they are not adjacent, then we randomly choose one of the two possible edge switches. If the chosen edge switch is feasible, that is, it does not involve adding an edge that already exists in GğºGitalic_G, then we go on and perform the edge switch. GğºGitalic_G is kept unchanged otherwise. After wğ‘¤witalic_w edge-switching attempts, we perform a connectivity test on GğºGitalic_G. If GğºGitalic_G turns out to be unconnected, then we undo all the edge switches performed during the previous wğ‘¤witalic_w edge-switching attempts.

Now let mğ‘šmitalic_m be the number of edges of GğºGitalic_G. Theorem 1.

A finite, irreducible, and aperiodic Markov chain converges to a unique stationary distribution regardless of the initial state.

Theorem 2.

CorollaryÂ 3, given next, follows directly from TheoremÂ 2.

Corollary 3.

3 Heuristics for parameter adjustment

As we remarked at the end of SectionÂ 1, adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w along the evolution of â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M is a viable alternative, aiming at better convergence properties, to fixing its value at the onset. In this section we discuss some heuristics to do this. Each transition consists now of performing wğ‘¤witalic_w edge-switching attempts, a connectivity test (with the ensuing possible undoing of all the edge switches performed during the wğ‘¤witalic_w attempts), and moreover an update of the value of wğ‘¤witalic_w. We consider two approaches to adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w. The first consists of a mechanism that is used in all existing heuristics for adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w in accordance with the result of the previous connectivity test. The other one is a new heuristic that adjusts wğ‘¤witalic_w aiming at approximating a given probability for the success of the next connectivity test. Notice that, in either case, CorollaryÂ 4 is no longer applicable and the convergence of â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M has to be re-examined.

3.1 Two current heuristics

As we demonstrate next, a Markov chain exists associated with this approach that has a uniform stationary distribution.

Two heuristics for adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w based on the outcome of the connectivity test have been proposed. However, by adopting our variation of the heuristic, which lets adjacent edge pairs be chosen as well, the probability of remaining at the same state is automatically reinforced. The other heuristic, due to Viger and Latapy [29] and henceforth referred to as the VL heuristic, is based on two parameters, q+superscriptğ‘q^{+}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and qâˆ’superscriptğ‘q^{-}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that q+>0superscriptğ‘0q^{+}>0italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 and 0<qâˆ’<10superscriptğ‘10<q^{-}<10 < italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1. 3.2 A new heuristic

Let Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± be such that 0<Î±<10ğ›¼10<\alpha<10 < italic_Î± < 1. We introduce a new heuristic to adjust wğ‘¤witalic_w whose goal is to achieve a constant probability Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± for the success of the next connectivity test. The new heuristic relies on a special connectivity test, whose details are described in AppendixÂ A, that not only checks whether GğºGitalic_G is connected but also calculates the probability that GğºGitalic_G remains connected after an edge-switching attempt. We refer to this new heuristic as the SB heuristic.

For 1â‰¤iâ‰¤|ğ’¢D|1ğ‘–subscriptğ’¢ğ·1\leq i\leq\left|{\cal G}_{D}\right|1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, let ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the probability that Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains connected after an edge-switching attempt. The SB heuristic is based on the assumption that the probability that a connectivity test succeeds after wğ‘¤witalic_w consecutive edge-switching attempts starting at Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (Ïi)wsuperscriptsubscriptğœŒğ‘–ğ‘¤(\rho_{i})^{w}( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In other words, we assume that the probability that a graph remains connected after each of the wğ‘¤witalic_w edge-switching attempts is ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and also that it suffices that one single edge switch yields an unconnected graph in order for the next connectivity test to be unsuccessful. We note that the latter assumption makes special sense under power-law node-degree distributions, since in such cases random node deletions are not likely to split the graph into more than one relatively large connected component [4, 10]. What this means is that, when an edge switch renders the graph unconnected, the forthcoming connectivity test can only succeed if a subsequent edge switch is performed on edges from different connected components, that is, most likely on at least one edge belonging to a relatively small connected component, which is a low-probability event.

In order to obtain ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we calculate the number of pairs of edges of Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on which performing an edge switch generates an unconnected graph. In AppendixÂ A we give a connectivity test that calculates the value of ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and is asymptotically no harder than depth-first search in the worst case.

Notice, however, that each graph Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT may have a different ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so the Markov chain modeling this method might converge to a stationary distribution that is different from the uniform distribution. For this reason, we define ÏÂ¯â¢(t)Â¯ğœŒğ‘¡\bar{\rho}(t)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG ( italic_t ) to be the average of every ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT obtained right after each of the first t+1ğ‘¡1t+1italic_t + 1 connectivity tests (the initial one and the tğ‘¡titalic_t others that correspond to transitions). We remark, finally, that as a consequence of wğ‘¤witalic_w being adjusted as a function of every ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ever obtained, the method cannot be modeled as a Markov chain and, to be rigorous, can no longer even be treated as a variation of the ESMC method in which another heuristic is used. However, if ÏÂ¯â¢(t)Â¯ğœŒğ‘¡\bar{\rho}(t)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG ( italic_t ) converges as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\inftyitalic_t â†’ âˆ, then wğ‘¤witalic_w also converges. In this case, wğ‘¤witalic_w approaches a constant and, as noted in SectionÂ 2, we once again have a method that can be modeled as a Markov chain having a uniform stationary distribution. In SectionÂ 4, our approach to assessing the convergence of ÏÂ¯â¢(t)Â¯ğœŒğ‘¡\bar{\rho}(t)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG ( italic_t ) (and of wğ‘¤witalic_w, consequently) is to compare the average value of gâ¢(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) at the end of an execution under the SB heuristic to those obtained under the GMZ and VL heuristics. As we demonstrate in that section, the figures for the SB heuristic vary within relatively small percentages with respect to those of either of the other two heuristics and we take this as indication that ÏÂ¯â¢(t)Â¯ğœŒğ‘¡\bar{\rho}(t)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG ( italic_t ) is close to convergence. In what follows, then, we continue to refer to the SB heuristic as an alternative for use with the ESMC method.

4 Computational results

In this section we present computational results for the three heuristics of SectionÂ 3. We have concentrated on power laws with Ï„=2.0,2.1,â€¦,3.0ğœ2.02.1â€¦3.0\tau=2.0,2.1,\ldots,3.0italic_Ï„ = 2.0 , 2.1 , â€¦ , 3.0 and set n=103ğ‘›superscript103n=10^{3}italic_n = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. All experiments were carried out on a Pentium 4HT running at 3GHz with 1GB of main memory. All running times we report refer to total elapsed times under a Linux operating system hosting one single user.

Before discussing our experiments, we pause momentarily to elaborate on a curious behavior of the power-law distribution. From SectionÂ 1, we know that, in order for Dğ·Ditalic_D to be realizable, its average node degree must be no less than the average node degree of a tree, which is approximately 2222 for sufficiently large nğ‘›nitalic_n. For n=103ğ‘›superscript103n=10^{3}italic_n = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, this is expected to hold only for Ï„âª…2.47ğœ2.47\tau\lessapprox 2.47italic_Ï„ âª… 2.47, meaning that for Ï„âª†2.47greater-than-or-approximately-equalsğœ2.47\tau\gtrapprox 2.47italic_Ï„ âª† 2.47 Dğ·Ditalic_D is expected not to be realizable. By requiring realizability as we repeatedly sample Dğ·Ditalic_D from the power law, we are in fact making the node-degree distribution be slightly different from that very power law. What we have observed is that, for Ï„âª†2.47greater-than-or-approximately-equalsğœ2.47\tau\gtrapprox 2.47italic_Ï„ âª† 2.47, the node-degree variance for realizable degree sequences tends to increase with Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ while the number of edges remains roughly constant. These characteristics have affected the results we present next very strongly.

In our experiments, we used W=104ğ‘Šsuperscript104W=10^{4}italic_W = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For each value of Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, we sampled 600600600600 realizable degree sequences and, for each of them, executed the generation method using the three heuristics and two distinct halting conditions. We carried out the VL heuristic for q+=0.1,0.2,0.3superscriptğ‘0.10.20.3q^{+}=0.1,0.2,0.3italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.1 , 0.2 , 0.3 and set qâˆ’superscriptğ‘q^{-}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in such a way that q+/qâˆ’=eâˆ’1superscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘ğ‘’1q^{+}/q^{-}=e-1italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_e - 1. The SB heuristic was carried out for Î±=0.1,0.2,0.3ğ›¼0.10.20.3\alpha=0.1,0.2,0.3italic_Î± = 0.1 , 0.2 , 0.3.

We have focused on analyzing four indicators, each calculated from the 600600600600 executions with each heuristic and each halting condition. The first one, which we denote by Rconvsubscriptğ‘…convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is the ratio of the average gâ¢(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) value at the end of an execution to the average value of gÂ¯â¢(t)Â¯ğ‘”ğ‘¡\bar{g}(t)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_t ) also at the end of an execution. Rconvsubscriptğ‘…convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be used as a source of information on the convergence of the Markov chain, as we know that gÂ¯â¢(t)Â¯ğ‘”ğ‘¡\bar{g}(t)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_t ) is an unbiased estimator for gâ¢(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ). Generally, the deviation of Rconvsubscriptğ‘…convR_{\mathrm{conv}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from 1111 grows with how far the generated graph is from a uniformly random sample of ğ’¢Dsubscriptğ’¢ğ·{\cal G}_{D}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The second indicator, which we denote by Rswitchsubscriptğ‘…switchR_{\mathrm{switch}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_switch end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is the average number of edge switches performed during an execution that are not undone as a result of the connectivity test. The third indicator, which we denote by Rwsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¤R_{w}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is the average value of wğ‘¤witalic_w at the end of an execution. The last indicator, finally, is the average running time (in minutes) of an execution and is denoted by Rtimesubscriptğ‘…timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The average gain obtained with the SB heuristic is higher under this halting condition, which can be explained by noting that each transition is now slower than under the halting condition based on the clustering coefficient. As a consequence, it is under the average-distance halting condition that the impact of adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w properly is more strongly manifest. Also, and unlike what occurs with the first halting condition, the gain obtained with the SB heuristic is now higher when Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is around 2.42.42.42.4. This suggests that the choice for gâ¢(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ) depends on a careful consideration of each applicationâ€™s peculiarities. FigureÂ 6 presents, respectively in parts (a) and (b), the average Î¼ibsubscriptsuperscriptğœ‡bğ‘–\mu^{\mathrm{b}}_{i}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î¼icsubscriptsuperscriptğœ‡cğ‘–\mu^{\mathrm{c}}_{i}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the SB heuristic when the halting condition is based on the average distance between nodes. The results are similar to the ones shown in FigureÂ 4(a, b) for the halting condition based on the clustering coefficient. The plots for Rtimesubscriptğ‘…timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (FigureÂ 6(c)), on the other hand, show a very different behavior. For almost all values of Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, Rtimesubscriptğ‘…timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is now seen to increase slightly when pair cuts are ignored. The reason for this behavior seems to be an insufficient number of samples. In fact, we expect Rtimesubscriptğ‘…timeR_{\mathrm{time}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_time end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be very slightly smaller than that obtained when pair cuts are not ignored. Since the time complexity of calculating the average distance between nodes is significantly higher than that of a connectivity test, ignoring pair cuts is therefore expected to have a small impact on the overall running time of the method.

5 Conclusions

We have considered the problem of generating, uniformly at random, connected graphs that have a given degree sequence but no multiple edges or self-loops. We studied the ESMC method, which employs edge switches to transform a graph into another while preserving the degree sequence. This method consists of first deterministically finding a graph with the desired properties and then performing random edge switches and also connectivity tests to obtain a randomized result.

We showed that, if we attempt to perform a constant number wğ‘¤witalic_w of edge switches between successive connectivity tests, then the method can be modeled as a Markov chain having a uniform stationary distribution. We also showed that, if wğ‘¤witalic_w is not constant but rather is adjusted as a function of the last connectivity testâ€™s outcome, then the method can still be modeled as a Markov chain of uniform stationary distribution.

We have also introduced a new heuristic for adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w that depends on the probability that the graph being generated remains connected after an edge switch is attempted. In order to calculate this probability, we use a new connectivity test that has the same time and space complexities as depth-first search (cf.Â AppendixÂ A). Even though the resulting method cannot always be modeled as a Markov chain, we showed that there are circumstances under which it too converges to the uniform distribution.

One of the main issues regarding generation methods based on Markov chains is determining the number of transitions to be performed until the Markov chain is satisfactorily close to its stationary distribution. We have approached this issue by resorting to the pragmatic procedure of computing, after each transition, a certain function of the graph being generated, and halting the generation when the average of this function over all transitions seems to have converged. A proper choice for this function is essential to the efficacy of the method, but appears to require consideration on a case-by-case basis.

We have given computational results for power-law-based degree sequences. Our results contemplate two previous heuristics for adjusting wğ‘¤witalic_w and also our new heuristic, and were given for two distinct halting criteria. They show that our heuristic, on average, outperforms the two existing heuristics on power laws for which 2â‰¤Ï„â‰¤32ğœ32\leq\tau\leq 32 â‰¤ italic_Ï„ â‰¤ 3.

The ESMC method can be especially useful to generate a group of connected random graphs having the same degree sequence. After obtaining the first graph, we can continue performing a relatively small number of transitions to generate each additional instance, without having to run the method from its beginning. Finally, the ESMC method can be extended to generate random graphs having a given degree sequence and another desired property (e.g., graphs having the clustering coefficient limited to a given interval). We need only find a means of obtaining an initial graph having that property, then obtain an efficient procedure to test whether a graph has that property, and also show the irreducibility of the Markov chain, that is, show that there is a sequence of edge-switching attempts connecting any two graphs having the given degree sequence and the desired property.

A.3 Complexity

Let us now discuss the space and time complexities of this modified depth-first search.
